purpose.value: Run a short diagnostic calibration set (5-10 items in 2-5 minutes) to estimate current readiness without grading.

value: Item prompts aligned to assessment mode

purpose.value: Add confidence tags (H/M/L) for each calibrate item to separate knowledge gaps from confidence miscalibration.

value: Every calibrate item has an H/M/L tag

purpose.value: Convert calibrate misses into a deterministic top-3 weakness set that drives ENCODE method selection.

Structured 6-step encoding protocol for new terms. Sound (phonetic cue) → Function (true meaning) → Image (vivid visual tied to function) → Entwine (PIE method: personal meaning) → Resonance (learner confirms it clicks) → Lock (record as card/log). Each step is gated — don't skip ahead.

value: New term or concept to encode
Definition or meaning from source material
Blank note area for hook creation

value.mitigation: Gate each step; don't proceed without completion
Make it concrete, visual, and bizarre
If phonetics don't work, try acronym or first-letter cue
Add emotion, stakes, or personal relevance - why does this matter to YOU?

purpose.value: Learner generates their own encoding hook BEFORE the AI offers help. Start with your own association, metaphor, or mnemonic. AI only assists if you're stuck. Enforces active generation over passive reception.

value: New term or concept to encode

value.mitigation: Enforce 90-second wait before AI help
Require written attempt even if "bad"
Track self-generation rate; flag if <50%

purpose.value: Sketch the structure (anatomy, pathway, concept map) and label from memory. Fill gaps with source material.

value.mitigation: Physically cover source material
Emphasize accuracy over beauty; stick figures acceptable
Require different-color pen for filled gaps

purpose.value: Explain the concept aloud as if teaching a classmate. Identify points where explanation breaks down.

value.mitigation: Close source material during teach-back
Force "why?" after every statement
Record and listen back; gaps become obvious

purpose.value: Ask 'why?' 3-5 times in succession about a concept to build causal depth. Each answer becomes the premise for the next question. Based on elaborative interrogation (Dunlosky et al.).

value: Initial statement or fact to interrogate

value.mitigation: Each answer must introduce new information
Require minimum 3 levels
Verify each level against source

purpose.value: Verbalize your reasoning step-by-step while working through a problem or reading. Exposes gaps in logic and strengthens self-explanation. Based on Chi et al. self-explanation research.

value: Problem or passage to work through

value.mitigation: Must vocalize; silent defeats the purpose
Require "This means..." after each unit
Pause and note whenever hesitation occurs

purpose.value: After reading each paragraph or concept, pause and explain to yourself WHY each step follows from the previous one. Focus on explaining the reasoning, not just restating facts.

value.mitigation: Require causal connectors — "because", "therefore", "this leads to"
Explain everything; "obvious" often means "unexamined"
Written notes required; verbal insufficient

purpose.value: Trace the causal mechanism step-by-step: what triggers what, and why. Build a cause→effect chain from input to output. Especially useful for pathophysiology and physiological pathways.

value.mitigation: Require explicit A→B→C, not A→C
Must cite specific molecular/cellular mechanism
Actively look for branch points and parallel effects

purpose.value: Build a node-and-link diagram showing relationships between concepts. Self-constructed maps force elaboration and reveal structural gaps. Use Mermaid syntax for dashboard editor.

value: Topic with multiple related concepts (5-15 nodes)

value.mitigation: Require relationship type on every link
Require at least 2 cross-links between peripheral nodes
Limit to 15 nodes; chunk into sub-maps if needed

purpose.value: Create a side-by-side table comparing 2-4 confusable concepts across shared features. Highlight discriminating features. Builds differential diagnosis skill.

value.mitigation: Limit to 5-7 rows; prioritize clinical relevance
Force ranking — which row is MOST differentiating?
Fill from memory first, then verify

purpose.value: Draw a sequential diagram showing a process, pathway, or algorithm. Include decision points where applicable. Use Mermaid graph TD syntax for dashboard editor.

value.mitigation: Every diamond must have labeled Yes/No paths
Actively look for loops and feedback
Split into sub-processes if >12 steps

purpose.value: Build a branching decision diagram: presentation → key findings → differential → tests → diagnosis. Scaffolds clinical reasoning into explicit decision points.

value.mode: Too many branches at one node
value.mitigation: Limit to 2-3 branches per decision point
Each question must meaningfully narrow differential
Always include "skip to emergency" path

purpose.value: Use spatial memory to encode ordered sequences by associating items with familiar locations. Based on the ancient Method of Loci used by Greek orators and memory champions.

value: List of items to memorize (5-10 optimal)

value.mitigation: Use your actual home, not imagined places
Add action, emotion, exaggeration
Max 10 per palace; create new palace for more

purpose.value: Create a bizarre narrative story connecting unrelated items. The absurdity makes it memorable without spatial locations.

value: List of items to memorize in order

value.mitigation: Add absurd elements; gravity-defying, impossible actions
Make interactions sensory and emotional
Split into multiple chains if >8 items

purpose.value: Create an analogy linking this concept to something familiar. Test if the analogy holds at the edges.

value: Analogy statement (A is to B as X is to Y)

value.mitigation: Require structural mapping, not just surface similarity
Force identification of at least one limitation
Choose domains you know well

purpose.value: Apply the concept to a clinical scenario. Ask: how would this present? What would you test? How would you treat?

value: All three questions answered (present, test, treat)

value.mitigation: Require specific patient characteristics
Must include at least 2 tests/assessments
Explain WHY this treatment for this patient

purpose.value: Identify 2-3 connections between this topic and topics from other courses. Look for shared principles.

value.mitigation: Require specific shared mechanism or structure
At least one must be from a different course
Each connection needs a "because" statement

purpose.value: Place two confusable concepts in a comparison table (features, functions, clinical signs). Identify discriminating features. Builds differential diagnosis skill.

value.mitigation: Focus on dimensions where they differ
Force ranking — which row is MOST differentiating?
Fill from memory first

purpose.value: Walk through a clinical case from presentation to assessment to intervention. Apply learned concepts to patient scenarios. Builds clinical reasoning chains.

value: Case fully walked through (presentation to intervention)

value.mitigation: Require explicit differential before diagnosis
Every test needs a "because I want to rule in/out..."
Explicitly name which concepts the case applies

purpose.value: For a condition, build the illness script: (1) enabling conditions, (2) pathophysiological fault, (3) clinical consequences. Compare your script to the textbook version.

value.mitigation: Require explicit pathophysiological link
Be specific — which risk factors are most important?
Always add "unlike [X] which has..."

purpose.value: Answer three questions: (1) What did I learn? (2) What's still muddy? (3) What's my next action?

value: Session notes or artifacts for reference
Next action is specific and actionable
Exit ticket logged to session record

value.mitigation: Force specificity — name actual concepts, facts, or skills
Something is always muddy — dig for it
Next action must pass the "could I do this in 15 min?" test

purpose.value: Draft 3-5 Anki cards for the session's key concepts. Use cloze or basic format. Brain syncs to Anki.

value: Card draft staging area (Brain or text file)
Cards tagged by topic and source
Cards staged in Brain for Anki sync
Card count logged to session record
Output ONLY canonical card blocks. No prose before/after cards.
Do not use bullets, markdown tables, CSV, or JSON.
Every card has TYPE, FRONT, BACK, TAGS label lines

value.mitigation: Split into separate cards — one fact each
If answer takes > 10 seconds to recall, simplify

value.mode: Drafting cards for material not yet understood
value.mitigation: Only card concepts you can already explain — cards are for retention, not learning

purpose.value: Build an interleaved drill sheet (30-60 timed items) and define cross-session validation checks.
Free-write everything you already know about the topic for 2-3 min. Surfaces prior knowledge and sets a baseline.

value: Topic name or concept to study
You've exhausted everything you can recall

value.mitigation: Remind that messy is fine — this is a dump, not a draft
Enforce strict timer; value is in the constraint
Close all references before starting

purpose.value: Write 3-5 questions you expect the material to answer. Creates forward hooks for active reading.

value: Brief overview (syllabus, chapter title, or slide deck title)

value.mitigation: Require specificity: 'What are the 3 types of...' not 'What is this about?'
Cover/close content until questions are written
Ranking activates metacognitive engagement

purpose.value: List related concepts you already know. Identify connections to previous modules.

value.mitigation: Prompt with broader categories — anatomy, physiology, pathology
Require relationship labels on arrows
Text list is acceptable; visual is optional enhancement

purpose.value: Have Tutor generate a topic skeleton with main headings and subheadings. Review for 2-3 min to build mental map.

value.mitigation: Request 2 levels only (headings + subheadings)
Goal is orientation, not retention
Cross-check against source materials; flag discrepancies

purpose.value: Group related terms/concepts into 3-5 clusters. Identify hierarchy and relationships.

value: List of terms/concepts from the topic (10-20 items)

value.mitigation: Force consolidation; look for super-categories

value.mode: Clusters too uneven (one has 80% of terms)
value.mitigation: Split large clusters by sub-function
Create "Misc" cluster; these may be edge cases or prerequisites

purpose.value: Break topic into 3 layers: big picture, key details, edge cases. Process one layer at a time.

value: Three-column template (Big Picture | Key Details | Edge Cases)

value.mitigation: Big Picture should be 1-2 sentences max; force brevity

value.mode: Skipping to edge cases too early
value.mitigation: Gate Layer 3 until Layer 2 is solid
Require specific facts, not summaries

purpose.value: Attempt to answer questions on the topic BEFORE studying it. Getting answers wrong primes the brain to encode the correct information more deeply.

value: Pre-test questions (3-5 questions on upcoming topic)

value.mitigation: Delay answer checking until after encoding phase
Require an answer for every question; guessing is the point
Include mix of difficulty; some should be answerable from prior knowledge

purpose.value: Extract a compact structural spine from source material before detail work. Build at most 12 high-signal nodes and link each node to one objective.
Audit what matters most before studying. Separate must-know targets from nice-to-know detail and set explicit goal targets for this run.
Review errors from retrieval practice. For each error: (1) What did I say? (2) What's correct? (3) Why did I confuse them? (4) What cue will prevent this next time? Metacognitive error analysis.

value: List of errors from recent retrieval practice
Root cause analysis for each error
Each error has a prevention cue
High-value errors converted to study artifacts

value.mitigation: Column 3 (Why confused?) is mandatory — dig into the root cause
No closure without a specific cue to prevent recurrence
Assume the error reveals something to learn — own it

purpose.value: Re-study items missed during retrieval, then immediately re-test. Repeat until all items are recalled correctly. Based on successive relearning (Rawson & Dunlosky).

value: List of missed items from retrieval practice
Mastery achieved on all targeted items
All items recalled correctly at least once
Maximum loop limit reached (e.g., 5 loops per item)
Time budget exhausted (with partial progress logged)

value.mitigation: Keep re-study brief (30-60 sec) — the test is where learning happens

value.mode: Stopping after first correct recall (no overlearning)
value.mitigation: For weak items, aim for 2 correct recalls before moving on
Loop counts are diagnostic — always record them

purpose.value: Build a single-page reference anchor containing minimal definitions, decision rules, canonical examples, near-misses, and traps.

value: Definitions, decision rules, examples, near-miss, traps all present

purpose.value: Generate a mode-tagged seed bank of 10-20 retrieval questions from objectives and anchor artifacts.

value: At least 10 and at most 20 items
Every item tagged by objective and assessment mode

purpose.value: Close materials. Write everything you remember about the topic. No peeking. Compare after.

value: Reference materials (closed during recall, opened for comparison)
Free recall dump (raw text with gaps marked)
Accuracy assessment (what was correct vs. incorrect)
You've exhausted everything you can recall

value.mitigation: Physically move materials out of sight before starting

value.mode: Stopping too early when recall feels hard
value.mitigation: Push through the difficulty — that's where learning happens
Comparison is mandatory — it's where you learn what you missed

purpose.value: Rapid-fire Q&A with Tutor. 10-15 questions in 5 min. Track accuracy for RSR.

value: Topic or concept set for quiz
RSR threshold achieved (if targeting specific level)

value.mitigation: Treat as test conditions — no references allowed
Force binary commit before seeing correct answer
RSR is the whole point — always calculate and log

purpose.value: Review notes with key terms blanked out. Fill from memory. Targets specific vocabulary recall.

value: Notes or text with key terms identified
Cloze deletion tool (or manually blanked printout)
Second pass on missed items complete

value.mitigation: 1 blank per sentence maximum; focus on highest-value terms

value.mode: Using blanks that have no context clues
value.mitigation: Ensure surrounding context provides retrieval cues
Say/write answer before looking — no peeking

purpose.value: Interleave questions from 2-3 different topics in a single retrieval block. Builds discrimination and prevents blocked-practice illusion. Based on interleaving research (Rohrer et al.).

value: Question bank or Tutor AI covering all topics
Randomization method (shuffle cards, AI random selection)
Confusion matrix (which topics got mixed up)
All questions in the mixed set answered
Discrimination accuracy meets threshold (can correctly identify topic)

value.mode: Blocked practice creeping in (doing all topic A, then all topic B)
value.mitigation: Enforce randomization — shuffle before starting

value.mode: Not tracking which topic each question belongs to
value.mitigation: Label each question with its topic before answering

value.mode: Frustration at harder recall (interleaving feels harder)
value.mitigation: Remind that difficulty is the point — harder now, easier later

purpose.value: Retrieve the same concept in 3 different formats: (1) free recall, (2) application question, (3) compare/contrast. Varied retrieval contexts build more flexible memory traces.

value: Single concept or topic to retrieve
Three retrieval format prompts (free recall, application, compare/contrast)
Reference materials for verification (closed during retrieval)
Three retrieval outputs (free recall, application, compare/contrast)

value.mode: Rushing through formats without genuine retrieval effort
value.mitigation: Treat each format as a separate mini-test — commit before checking

value.mode: Picking a concept you don't know well enough yet
value.mitigation: Variable retrieval is for flexibility — use on already-encoded material
Compare/contrast is often hardest — don't skip it

purpose.value: Run near-miss adversarial prompts that force distinction between confusable concepts under low support.

value: Confusable pairs from Spine or ErrorLog

purpose.value: Execute timed retrieval sprints and record latency per item to expose speed bottlenecks.
